entry.value: This page features customised javascript actions in Rapid

Recommended for the more tech savy users, Rapid allows you to create your own customised actions written in javascript. The possibilities are near endless when using the custom action, and you can even target specific controls in Rapid providing they are referenced in the correct way. On this page we will be going into detail on some examples that you can use in your own Rapid applications.
To get you started we will be using basic javascript and then move on to more advanced examples. For our first example we will be linking to an external website through a new tab in your browser.

Linking to another website is a very common piece of javascript to use due to it's versatility and how often we find ourselves wanting to link to other sites. With this covered, we are going to move on to something a little different. Our next example will display a popup box with a message to display. These are otherwise known as alert boxes. To begin we will start with a simple introductory example.
alert("Welcome to the Rapid test demo. This is a sample message!");
Another way to use alerts is to have their message change based on what a user enters. In this next example anything that is entered in the input box will display as the alert message.

As our custom action is written using javascript it can also call methods in various jQuery libraries. These libraries can be those you have imported yourself, or those that are within Rapid. Our example here will copy the value of our date control, place it in an input box, and change the formatting to something different.

A similar type of custom action is to copy the value of an input box and place it inside of a dropdown list. It is relatively easy to do this in order to replace the whole dropdown list, however in this example we want to provide something more usable and append to the list.
